importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: Green card holders filing for citizenship after October 20, 2025, will be subject to the new, stricter citizenship test.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The changes to the naturalization process, including the new civics test, will be implemented starting October 20, 2025.

keyTakeAways: The Trump administration is implementing a stricter naturalization process, requiring applicants to answer 12 out of 20 questions correctly, doubling the previous requirement of 6 out of 10.

The list of possible questions is expanding from 100 to 128, with many being more difficult and including complex historical questions such as the reasons behind the U.S. involvement in the Persian Gulf War and the Vietnam War.
Easier questions about geography (e.g., which ocean is on the West Coast of the U.S.) are being removed or reduced.

Applicants must now demonstrate 'good moral character' by submitting evidence of positive contributions to American society, and immigration officers may interview coworkers, family members, or neighbors.
USCIS Director Joseph Edlow claims the current test is 'too easy' and argues that increased rigor ensures a deeper attachment to the Constitution and U.S. values.

Critics, including immigration law professor Amanda Frost, argue there is no evidence that the current process allows individuals who do not share American values to naturalize, and that immigrants and their descendants have historically contributed to the U.S. economy and society.

Advocacy groups warn that the changes may disproportionately affect low-literacy individuals and those without access to preparation materials, potentially reducing naturalization rates and increasing uncertainty in the process.

namedEntities.name: Trump administration
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A political entity representing the executive branch of the U.S. government under President Donald Trump
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Trump administration is responsible for instituting the new, stricter citizenship test and policy changes to the naturalization process.

namedEntities.name: U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services (USCIS)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A federal agency responsible for administering the naturalization process and immigration-related policies
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: USCIS is directly implementing the changes to the citizenship test, including increasing the number of correct answers required and expanding the question pool.

namedEntities.name: Matthew Tragesser
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A USCIS spokesman who commented on the new citizenship test policy
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He provided an official statement explaining that the new test ensures applicants are 'fully assimilated and will contribute to America's greatness'.

namedEntities.name: Joseph Edlow
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: USCIS Director who criticized the current civics test as 'too easy'
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He stated that the test needs to be more rigorous to ensure applicants have a true attachment to the Constitution and U.S. values.

namedEntities.name: Amanda Frost
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Professor of immigration law at the University of Virginia and author of 'You Are Not American'
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: She critiques the policy changes, arguing there is no evidence that the naturalization process allows people who don't share American values to become citizens.

namedEntities.name: Julie Mitchell
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Legal director of the Central American Resource Center in Los Angeles
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: She expresses concern that the changes will create greater barriers for low-literacy applicants and those without access to preparation materials.

namedEntities.name: Persian Gulf War
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A military conflict involving the United States and Iraq, during which the U.S. invaded Kuwait in 1990–1991
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It is one of the new, more difficult questions on the civics test, requiring applicants to explain the U.S. rationale for involvement.

namedEntities.name: Vietnam War
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A 1955–1975 conflict in which the United States supported anti-communist forces in Vietnam
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It is one of the new, complex questions on the civics test, requiring applicants to provide a historical rationale for U.S. involvement.

namedEntities.name: Green card holders
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Individuals who have been granted lawful permanent residency in the United States
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: They are the primary group affected by the new citizenship test requirements, especially those filing after October 20, 2025.

namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A list of the top 500 largest companies in the United States by revenue
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Used by Professor Amanda Frost to demonstrate that immigrants and their descendants have significantly contributed to U.S. economic success.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The Trump administration is making it harder for immigrants to become U.S. citizens by implementing a stricter naturalization test. Starting October 20, 2025, applicants will need to answer 12 out of 20 questions correctly—doubling the previous requirement of 6 out of 10. The list of possible questions will grow from 100 to 128 and include more difficult, historically complex questions such as the reasons for U.S. involvement in the Persian Gulf and Vietnam Wars. Easier questions on geography and basic facts are being removed. Applicants must now prove 'good moral character' through evidence of positive contributions to society and may face interviews with coworkers, neighbors, or family members. While USCIS officials argue the test ensures deeper assimilation and values alignment, critics like Professor Amanda Frost and advocacy group leaders such as Julie Mitchell say there is no evidence that the current process allows people who don't share American values to naturalize, and that the changes may disproportionately affect low-literacy individuals and those without access to preparation materials, possibly reducing naturalization rates and increasing uncertainty.
title: The test for U.S. citizenship is about to get harder
